pr_title: [core] New RuleSet API and deprecations for PMD's entry point APIs

timeline.message:
Replace createFactory methods with a builder

Deprecate compatibility filter

Deprecate methods in RulesetsFactUtils
Stop parsing comma-separated paths by default

timeline.bodyText: Should we mark this as experimental? Or would we just deprecate this as well, if we have a better PMD programmatic API?
timeline.author: adangel

replies.bodyText: It may be possible to preserve compatibility with this signature in PMD 7. But also I think we should ideally keep a published entry point, that remains non-deprecated in the 6.x release cycle
replies.author: oowekyala

timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure we should deprecate this.
I kinda like the idea, that we would provide all exceptions (if we throw any) with a common super type.
Of course, the exception should be not a checked exception like this one, but rather a runtime exception.
We maybe need additionally an internal exception that we would convert into such a public API exception.
But that's out of scope of this PR - that's the question of exception handling.
timeline.author: adangel

replies.bodyText:
I think in this PR all APIs that throw PMDException are being deprecated (I did not check thoroughly), which is why I went ahead. I think we can do better with exceptions, but I'm not sure PMDException as it stands does anything useful.
But yes it would be nice to have a common supertype in pmd 7.
replies.author: oowekyala

timeline.bodyText:
Isn't that used by pmd-doc? And I think, it's used by eclipse-pmd-plugin as well. We probably need to think, whether we can really remove it or whether we need to provide an alternative.
The method sounds more like some utility/helper method, to get all rules of all languages on the classpath.

timeline.bodyText:
Hm... part of this class is a builder not a parser....
Maybe we can start with phrasing what this class does: Loads rulesets from files (or other resources). The way, the rulesets are loaded, can be configured - hence configurable.
Not sure, if this is more a RuleSetBuilder, RuleSetLoader or RuleSetParser (well in PMD6 the impl of the parser is actually in RuleSetFactory, but that's only for now).
Since I came across RuleSetWriter... maybe this is a RuleSetReader? (Although this would make one think as a java.io.Reader, which works a bit different)
timeline.author: adangel

replies.bodyText: RulesetLoader sounds good! I would avoid RulesetReader, sounds like something that uses a ruleset, not something that creates it. I think we could rename RulesetFactory to RulesetParser eventually
replies.author: oowekyala

timeline.author: adangel

timeline.bodyText: I think, we don't need the try-finally here - the files are opened/closed in the other processFiles method
timeline.author: adangel

timeline.bodyText:
That's an interesting information. At some point, we should define that with a specific exception.
But: do we at this position actually know, what file we were analyzing? This is the outer catch, so ctx is maybe the last one. And in case of multi threading, the ctx here is not used at all.... or do I miss something here?
Runtime Exception are already handled in PmdRunnable and added there as errors to the report... So, I'm not sure, which RuntimeExceptions we would get here...
timeline.author: adangel

replies.bodyText: I introduced that as a workaround for PMDTask, because the new entry point hides its RuleContext. Before, PMDTask was querying the RuleContext when there was an exception. So, I don't know if this makes sense, but it should match the current behavior. We can do better in PMD7. I'd like to introduce FileAnalysisException, which is a supertype for eg TokenMgrError and ParseException, and has a file name.
replies.author: oowekyala

replies.bodyText:
Hm... Maybe PMDTask was/is already wrong?
FileAnalysisException sounds good.
replies.author: adangel
